title: Introduction to Policy Sciences
description: This course introduces key concepts, theories and models in the study of policy sciences. To resolve complex and multi-level public problems of a globalized world in ways that help to identify and enhance the common interest, policy sciences provide an integrated and interdisciplinary approach for making good policy decisions. This course also aims to help students understand the process and structure in designing policies. The concerns of this course are integrating theory and practice into actionable social knowledge and apply it to real world problems.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to: a. Understand the policy process and its application in real life policies; b. Understand key concepts and theoretical approaches to public sciences and analysis; c. Adopt and apply theories to understand real world problems; d. Formulate their own knowledge system based on the knowledge and concepts introduced.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to Policy Sciences and public policy  2. Basic concepts & theories in Policy Sciences 3. Key models and frameworks in Policy Analysis  4. Wicked problems & international affairs in the globalized world 5. Integrated and interdisciplinary approach for policy-making 6. Main process and structure in designing and evaluating policies 7. Theories and its application in the context of Hong Kong and comparative contexts
required_readings: - Howlett, M., Ramesh, M., & Perl, A. (2009). Studying public policy: Policy cycles and policy subsystems (Vol. 3). Oxford: Oxford University Press. - Sabatier, P. A., & Weible, C. M. (Eds.). (2014). Theories of the policy process. Westview Press.
recommended_readings: - Birkland, T. A. (2015). An introduction to the policy process: Theories, concepts, and models of public policy making. Routledge. - Hajer, M., Hajer, M. A., & Wagenaar, H. (Eds.). (2003). Deliberative policy analysis: understanding governance in the network society. Cambridge University Press. - Innes, J. E., & Booher, D. E. (2010). Planning with complexity: An introduction to collaborative rationality for public policy. Routledge.

locations: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

title: Data Science and Public Policy
description: This course focuses on the important connection between data science and public policy by identifying and analyzing the policy challenges posed by data science technologies. It assesses what policy options and tools are available to address them and examines what new capacities governments and also citizens must develop in the era of data science. Students would also be introduced to the professional and ethical responsibilities and social, economic, political and legal impacts under the changes and innovations brought by data science.

title: Foundation of Data Science
description: This course is intended for students with little or no programming experience. It is designed to provide students with a firm foundation for learning modern data science, which uses computer programming to wrangle and analyze data. Adopting a hands-on approach, this course covers all the basics of programming in Python, as well as general computer programming concepts and techniques, such as branching, looping and inheritance. It also familiarizes students with some of the most useful Python libraries for data science, such as NumPy, pandas and matplotlib. This course plays a foundational role in the data science curriculum.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Understand the role computation can play in solving problems. Understand the basic programming concepts and techniques. Write programs in Python that allow them to accomplish useful goals.  Use Python libraries to complete simple data science tasks.
syllabus: Values and Variables   Simple Data Types: int, float, string, boolean  Lists  Conditional Statements: if, if-else, if-elif-else  Dictionaries  User Input   Iteration: for loops, while loops  Functions and Modules  Classes and Objects  Files  Exceptions  Python libraries for data science: NumPy, pandas, matplotlib.

title: Statistics for Data Science and Policy Studies
description: This course provides an introduction to data science and its applications in policy analysis. Students will learn the fundamental concepts of statistics and probability theory and their role in policy research. Through hands-on exercises and case studies, students will gain practical experience in descriptive statistics, probability distributions, statistical inference, and analysis. Students will also develop skills in communicating statistical results to policy audiences through effective writing and data visualization techniques. By the end of the course, students will have a solid understanding of statistical methods commonly used in policy analysis and be able to apply them to real-world problems in policy studies.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Analyze and interpret policy data using descriptive statistics and statistical inference techniques. Apply appropriate statistical tests, such as t-tests and ANOVA, to policy data to answer research questions. Demonstrate proficiency in communicating statistical results to policy audiences through effective writing and data visualization techniques. Apply statistical techniques to solve real-world problems in policy analysis and data science.
syllabus: Introduction to Data Science, Statistics, and Policy Analysis  Overview of data science and policy analysis Role of statistics in policy analysis   Descriptive Statistics  Measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode) Measures of variability (range, variance, standard deviation) Probability distributions and histograms Box plots and scatter plots   Probability distributions  Basic concepts of probability theory Discrete and continuous probability distributions  Random variables and expected values   Inferential Statistics  Sampling distributions and the central limit theorem Point estimation and interval estimation Hypothesis testing and p-values Statistical power and effect size Type I and Type II errors   Choice of Statistical Tests  For example: T-test, ANOVA, and Chi-square test   Regression and Prediction  Correlation analysis Simple linear regression analysis   Communicating Statistical Results in a Policy Context  Writing statistical reports for policy audiences Creating effective data visualizations for policy audiences Interpreting and communicating statistical results for policy audiences
required_readings: Bruce, P. C., Bruce, A., & Gedeck, P. (2020). Practical statistics for data scientists : 50+ essential concepts using R and Python (Second edition.). O’Reilly Media, Inc.
recommended_readings: Salcedo, J. (2017). Basic Statistics and Data Mining for Data Science (1st edition). Packt Publishing. [Video]Rahman, A. (2020). Statistics for Data Science and Policy Analysis (A. Rahman, Ed.; 1st ed. 2020.). Springer Singapore.

title: Research Methods for Policy Studies
description: This course introduces major methods used in policy studies research, with both quantitative and qualitative methods as the foci. This course discusses major methodological issues, stages and process of research, the use of appropriate methods, strategies and tools with the objective of enabling students to adopt a multimethod and critical approach to conduct research of public policies and data science. Course contents also include the interpretation and communication of findings to different stakeholders, research ethics and limitations, and using research to generate impact.

title: Introduction to Data Science Applications in Public Policy and Political Studies
description: This introductory course explores the intersection of data science, public policy, and political studies. Students will learn how to utilize data analysis methods to understand and analyze public policy issues and the political process. The course will cover basic concepts in data science, including data collection, cleaning, analysis, and visualization, with a focus on applications in policy and political studies. Students will also learn how to critically evaluate and interpret data to inform decision-making in the public policy and political domains. Through hands-on projects and laboratory sessions, students will develop practical skills in using data to address real-world policy challenges and political issues. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with the tools and knowledge to apply data science techniques to analyze and understand the complexities of public policy and the political landscape.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to: 1. Understand the foundational principles of data science and how they can be applied to analyze public policy issues and political processes.2. Develop proficiency in data collection, cleaning, analysis, and visualization techniques relevant to policy and political studies.3. Critically evaluate and interpret data to draw meaningful insights and make informed decisions in the context of public policy and political analysis.4. Apply data science methods to address real-world policy challenges and political issues, demonstrating the ability to use data-driven approaches to inform and shape policy decisions.
syllabus: Explore Data Science in Public Policy and Political Studies Build Critical Analysis and Evidence-Based Reasoning Skills Master Techniques for Collecting and Preparing Data Utilize Effective Data Visualization for Clear Communication Study Real-World Case Studies in Data-Driven Policy Collaborate on Projects Addressing Current Policy Challenges
required_readings: - Agresti, A., Franklin, C. A., Klingenberg, B. (2016). Statistics: The art and science of learning from data. 4th ed. NY: Pearson. - Gorard, S. (2003). Quantitative methods in social science research. NY: Continuum. - Miller, J. D. (2017). Statistics for Data Science. UK: Packt.

title: Intermediate Data Science Applications in Public Policy and Political Studies
description: This intermediate course serves as a continuation of the exploration of data science methods in the context of public policy and political studies. Students will delve deeper into data analysis techniques and their application to understanding policy issues and political processes. The course is designed to further develop students' skills in data visualization, statistical analysis, and data interpretation, with a specific focus on their relevance to policy formulation and political decision-making. Through hands-on projects and laboratory sessions, students will enhance their data science proficiency and learn how to effectively communicate data-driven insights to stakeholders in the public sector. By the end of the course, students will be equipped to apply intermediate data science techniques to analyze and address policy challenges and political dynamics, building upon the foundational knowledge gained in the introductory course.

title: Advanced Programming for Data Science
description: This course is designed for students with prior programming experience interested in learning C# programming and game development. The course covers fundamental programming concepts like object-oriented programming, control structures, collections, and error handling in C#. Students will also learn how to create games with Unity, including working with the Unity editor, physics engine, game assets, and game AI.The course begins with an introduction to C# programming language and control structures and gradually progresses to advanced programming concepts, such as inheritance and polymorphism. Additionally, students will learn how to handle errors and debug code.The second half of the course focuses on Unity game development. Students will learn to use the Unity editor to create game objects, scenes, and gameplay mechanics. They will also learn to work with some of Unity's built-in features, e.g., animations, particle effects, and game AI.By the end of the course, students will have the skills and knowledge necessary to write a C# program and build a fully functional and engaging game with Unity.

title: Data Preprocessing for Data Analytics
description: This course teaches students the major computing applications and coding languages, such as Python, of data analytics and how to apply them in public policy. The emphasis of the course is to apply data analytics to make theory-guided and data-driven policy decisions. With the technical competence provided by the course, students are expected to be both a skillful user of data analytics and an intelligent policymaker informed by data science. This course focuses on the data preprocessing stage in the data science lifecycle and teaches the efficient use of powerful tools for data preprocessing such as pandas.
outcome: Students are expected to acquire the basic knowledge of computing applications and coding languages, such as Python, of data analytics and apply it to solve problems in public policy.
syllabus: 1) Introduction to data analytics for public policy  2) Quantitative research design and basic methods for analysis 3) Understanding the application of major computing applications and coding languages, such as Python 4) Basic knowledge in data collecting, data cleaning and analysis  5) Interpreting research results in different models

title: Database Systems for Data Science
description: This course covers the fundamental concepts of database systems and their role in data science projects. Students will gain practical experience working with relational databases, as well as learn how to design effective data models and optimize database performance. Topics covered may include SQL basics, entity-relationship modeling, normalization, indexing, and query optimization. This course is ideal for individuals with prior programming experience interested in learning about databases for data science.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Create effective data models using entity-relationship diagrams and normalization techniques. Write SQL queries to retrieve and manipulate data from relational databases. Evaluate the performance of database systems. Apply database systems to real-world examples.

title: Policy Analysis and Design Thinking
description: This course integrates public policy analysis and design thinking to give students an integrated and comprehensive approach of resolving public problems. Design thinking, with its key features of being solution-based, user involvement, co-creation of knowledge, co-evolution of solution and problem, complements the economics-based and analytical model of public policy analysis well. Together they strengthen students’ ability in serving the dual role of a capable policy designer and an effective analyst who solve the policy problem and satisfy the diverse concerns of stakeholders.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to: a. Understand the process of policy making and steps and theoretical perspectives of design thinking; b. Apply the framework of design thinking in policymaking; c. Analyze policy from different stakeholders’ perspectives in policy design;  d. Have a solid foundation of policy design and analysis.
syllabus: 1) Basic knowledge in public policy analysis (key concepts, major theories, main methods) 2) Integrated and comprehensive approach in resolving public problem from a design thinking perspective 3) Process of policy making, understanding key factors (e.g., common interest, stakeholders, interest groups, etc.） 4) Understanding actors in policy design, their roles, and interaction dynamics  5) Acquiring knowledge about analytical model of public policy analysis

title: AI Governance and Public Policy
description: The course offers an insightful and comprehensive exploration of the dynamic landscape surrounding the governance and public policies of artificial intelligence (AI). By focusing on the intersection of AI, governance, and public policy, it empowers students to navigate the multifaceted challenges. Through a combination of theoretical analysis, case studies, and interactive discussions, students will develop a profound understanding of AI strategies and governance frameworks and the formulation of responsible public policies in both national and global contexts. The course will equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary to shape the future of AI in the role of policymaker and major stakeholders in civil society.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to:  Develop a comprehensive understanding of AI strategies and governance in both national and global contexts. Analyze and evaluate different AI governance frameworks and strategies, considering their effectiveness and impact on transparency, fairness, accountability, and other important public values. Apply critical thinking skills to assess the potential risks and benefits associated with AI technologies and their implementation, and propose responsible policies to mitigate those risks. Demonstrate knowledge of the competing concerns and dilemmas related to AI such as privacy, data security, economic growth, and ethical considerations, and formulate policies that address them. Engage in interdisciplinary discussions and collaborations to address the complex challenges at the intersection of AI, governance, and public policy.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to AI Governance and Public Policy Overview of AI technologies and their impact on governance and public policy Role of AI in shaping public policies2. Transparency, Fairness, and Bias in AI Understanding the importance of transparency and explain ability in AI systems Assessing and mitigating biases in AI algorithms and decision-making processes Policies for ensuring fairness and accountability in AI governance3. Ethical Frameworks and Accountability for AI Governance Examination of ethical principles and guidelines in AI governance Ethical considerations in AI decision-making and algorithmic accountability4. Legal and Regulatory Landscape for AI Analysis of existing laws and regulations applicable to AI technologies Privacy concerns in AI applications and data-driven decision-making Policy frameworks for AI regulation and legal challenges in governing AI5. AI Governance in a Global Perspective Major paradigms, models, and approaches in AI governance AI governance in major regions and countries (e.g., China, US, and Europe)6. AI Governance and Public Sector Applications AI deployment in government services and public administration Policy considerations for AI adoption in public sector decision-making7. Stakeholder Engagement and Collaboration in AI Governance Engaging with diverse stakeholders in AI governance processes Multi-stakeholder collaborations for inclusive and participatory decision-making Building partnerships between governments, industry, academia, and civil society8. Future Trends and Emerging Issues in AI Governance Exploring the evolving landscape of AI technologies and their governance challenges Policy implications and strategies for adapting to future AI advancements

title: Managing Technology and Policy Innovation
description: This course explores the dynamic intersection of technology and policy innovation, delving into theories and practical strategies essential for effective management. The course unfolds in two distinct parts, each addressing pivotal aspects of this interdisciplinary field. Firstly, it examines policy challenges stemming from technological advancements. Secondly, it investigates using policy to foster societal innovation. Students will gain insights into the interplay of technology, institutions, and society, essential for sustainable innovation. This course is ideal for students who are eager to understand and navigate the intricate relationship between technology and policy, and who seek to drive impactful innovation in a rapidly evolving societal landscape.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to:  a. Identify and understand key literature and theories on innovation in the public sector  b. Understand the interplay of technology and policy innovation  c. Identify the major factors driving the result and performance of innovation  d. Draw experience from both local and global perspectives in analyzing cases of technology and innovation
syllabus: 1) Technology and Policy Challenges (e.g., AI and the Future of Work)2) Technology and Societal Impact (e.g., Social Media and Governance)3) Theories and strategies of managing technology and policy innovation  4) Innovation system and innovation policies (e.g., mechanism and process of innovation and diffusion of technology)  5) Case studies in technology innovation and policy innovation

title: Data Science Project Management
description: Effective project management can lead to heightened efficiency and productivity while also mitigating the risk of failure. However, overseeing data science projects poses unique challenges due to the involvement of stakeholders from multiple teams and the necessity to balance both business and technical objectives. This course provides a comprehensive overview of the intersection between project management and data science. Students will explore how project management principles can enhance the management of data science projects and how data science methodologies can improve project management practices. While no prerequisites are required, this course is ideal for students who possess a basic understanding of data science. It is particularly suitable for students who harbor an interest in effectively managing data science projects and assembling teams.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Identify and describe fundamental project management knowledge and concepts. Apply project management principles to enhance the efficiency and productivity of data science projects. Explain the value of project management processes, tools and techniques. Critically assess case studies and real-world examples to understand the symbiotic relationship between project management and data science.

Overview of project management principles Understanding what you can do with data science  Understanding the intersection of project management and data science  Leveraging Project Management for Data Science Projects. Case Studies and Applications Analyzing case studies of successful integration of project management and data science Exploring industry-specific applications and best practices  Future Trends and Emerging Technologies. Emerging trends in project management and data science Utilizing data analytics for project forecasting and trend analysis Impact of artificial intelligence and automation on project management processes Ethical considerations and challenges in the convergence of project management and data science

title: Linear Algebra for Data Science
description: This course is designed to provide students with the essential foundational concepts of modern linear algebra for understanding contemporary data science and machine learning techniques. Stressing on intuition from coding rather than traditional mathematical proofs, this course approaches linear algebra from a computational perspective, where linear algebra concepts are implemented in Python code with a focus on applications in data science and machine learning. This course is ideal for students with prior programming experience who are interested in understanding modern linear algebra and its applications in data science and machine learning from a computational perspective.

title: Calculus for Data Science
description: This course is designed to provide students with the essential foundational concepts of calculus for understanding contemporary machine learning and data science algorithms in which calculus is used as an optimization tool. It approaches calculus, both single-variable and multivariate, from a computational perspective, stressing on intuition from coding rather than traditional mathematical proofs. This course is ideal for students with prior programming experience who are interested in understanding the powerful optimization algorithms used in modern data science and machine learning.

title: Big Data Analytics for Public Policy
description: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of Big Data computing systems and programming models. Students will gain hands-on experience working with mainstream open-source platforms for Big Data processing and analytics, including Hadoop and Spark. The course covers the architecture and components of Hadoop and Spark, data processing with Spark, and advanced topics such as Spark Streaming, graph processing, and machine learning. Students will learn to develop operational and programming tools for data collection, serialization, migration, and workflow coordination in Big Data pipelines. By the end of the course, students will be able to design and implement solutions to real-world Big Data problems using Hadoop or Spark. This course is ideal for students with prior programming and database experience interested in developing expertise in Big Data computing systems and programming models for processing and analyzing large-scale datasets.

title: Machine Learning for Public Policy
description: This course introduces students to the machine learning concepts and techniques that are relevant to policy analytics. Major topics include linear regression, predictive modeling, classification, resampling methods, dimension reduction techniques, principal component analysis, smoothing splines. Additional topics such as decision trees, support vector machines and clustering methods may also be introduced. Students will learn how to employ these methods to conduct supervised and unsupervised learning for social and policy analytics, and gain hands-on experience with real-life data using data science software.
outcome: Students are expected to: Understand the distinction between supervised and unsupervised learning, and identify appropriate tools to address research questions with “big data” Make use of the following supervised learning algorithms: linear and logistic regression, K-nearest neighbors, discriminant analysis, cross-validation and bootstrap, shrinkage estimation, generalized additive models, tree-based methods, and support vector machines in social and policy analysis Apply basic unsupervised procedures including clustering and principal components analysis in social and policy analysis Appreciate the bias-variance tradeoff and apply model selection methods based on cross-validation and bootstrapping to a prediction challenge Analyze real-world dataset using data science software
syllabus: Major topics include linear regression, predictive modeling, classification, resampling methods, dimension reduction techniques, principal component analysis, smoothing splines. Additional topics such as decision trees, support vector machines and clustering methods may also be introduced.

title: Collaborative Governance in a Global Context
description: This course aims to provide students with knowledge, skills and applications of collaborative governance in a rapidly changing globalized world. Collaborative governance is broadly defined as the processes and structures of public policy decision making and management that engage people constructively across the boundaries of public, private and civic society for a public purpose that could not otherwise be accomplished. With the increasingly limited role of government in governance, the ability of policymakers to collaborate with non-state actors across levels and boundaries becomes critical for addressing policy challenges. The course focuses on how collaborative governance can build consensus and deliberative purposes of public policy and governance through studying its formats, process, rationales, concepts and outcomes as well as evaluation of its effectiveness and dilemma. The course also intends to nurture students to have a responsible and reflective role in society and to pursue a better governance.

title: Data Science and Regulation
description: The course focuses on the regulatory issues and concerns when the governments take data science as a paradigm to enhance the capacity of public policy. Advance in data science radically transforms the way data can be handled and utilized, and inevitably generates new regulatory concerns and debates due to the clash of competing values and interests. For example, while privacy and citizen rights advocates strive to decrease unexpected uses of data, many scientists and institutions may attempt to use data to design and evaluate public policies in order to maximize its effectiveness. This course discusses theoretical approaches to regulations from multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary approaches for the analysis of regulatory institutions, practices and ideas in data regulation as well as the dillemma between utilization of data and its protection, accessibility and transparency.

title: Extended Reality (XR) for Data Visualization and Policy Narratives
description: In an era of technological advancement, AR/VR transcends traditional media types such as images, videos, text, and audio, offering a new medium for applications in data science and policy studies. This course explores the diverse applications of AR/VR technology in data visualization and policy narratives. Students gain practical skills in creating AR/VR experiences for visualizing complex data, crafting compelling narratives, and communicating policy insights. They will learn about AR/VR systems, principles for immersive experiences, human-centered design for AR/VR, and game development using cutting-edge platforms such as Unity. This course illuminates the potential of AR/VR as a powerful tool for visualizing ideas and communicating information with unparalleled depth and clarity. This course is ideal for students who are interested in exploring innovative applications of emerging technologies in data visualization, idea presentation, and policy communication and seek to harness AR/VR technology to innovate in these domains.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Describe the capabilities and limitations of AR/VR technology and their applications in policy design and analysis. Use game engines to create AR/VR applications. Use AR/VR for visualizing ideas and communicating information.
syllabus: Introduction to AR/VR Technology What is AR/VR technology? Different types of AR/VR systems and their capabilities. Examples of AR/VR applications in policy design and analysis. Unity for AR/VR App Development Introduction to Unity as a development platform for AR/VR apps. Fundamentals of creating AR/VR apps in Unity. Best practices for AR/VR app design. AR/VR Data Visualization and Policy Narratives Applying AR/VR technology to data visualization and policy narratives. Hands-on experience using AR/VR tools to present ideas. Collaboration and teamwork in AR/VR app development.

title: Smart Cities and Internet of Things
description: This course will introduce the concept of Smart Cities and explore how the Internet of Things (IoT) can help address urbanization challenges. Students will gain an understanding of the different components of IoT for Smart Cities, including sensor technologies, communication technologies, big data analytics, and security. The course will cover topics such as devices and communication protocols for IoT networks, big data analytics in the context of the IoT paradigm, IoT-enabled electric vehicles in smart cities, and blockchain technology for security and privacy in IoT. This course is ideal for students who wish to explore the opportunities of IoT in building a smarter city.

title: Computer Simulation for Policymaking
description: This course introduces the fundamentals of systems modeling and simulation, which are increasingly popular tools for developing, implementing, and evaluating public policy. The course will expose students to diverse system modeling and simulation approaches and emphasize their applications in policymaking to equip them with the skills they will need to conduct technically-focused policy analysis. Teaching is conducted through class lectures and tutorials related to simulation software applications (e.g., Anylogic). This course is ideal for individuals with prior programming experience interested in exploring computer simulation’s potential for policy design and analysis.

title: Policy Leadership and Entrepreneurship Workshop
description: This course studies how leadership and entrepreneurship are interrelated to create social and political impacts throughout the policy process, in particular, how leadership acts as an important factor to influence the social environment to nurture entrepreneurial activities. Leadership provides social source of influence and vision that one uses to inspire action taken by others, and to mobilize others to achieve a common goal. Entrepreneurship is the recognition of opportunities by coupling needs, wants, resources, and problems with innovative solutions and make changes to society. With a workshop format, the course provides students more interactive experience to equip them with the mindset, skills, and strategies of policy leadership and entrepreneurship. Policy leaders and entrepreneurs will be invited to serve as guest speakers in order to offer students the opportunities to learn from their practical experience.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to: Understand the concepts and theories of leadership and their practice in public policy Understand the concepts and theories of policy entrepreneurship and their practice Understand the relationships between policy leadership and entrepreneurship and how to integrate the two concepts to search for and respond to opportunities to have better results and innovations Apply the framework of policy leadership and entrepreneurship in major cases and policy areas across local and global contexts
syllabus: Foundation of policy leadership and entrepreneurship   Policy leadership and entrepreneurship in Hong Kong and major countries  Global governance and network under policy leadership and entrepreneurship  Application of policy leadership and entrepreneurship in major policy areas   Future research and agenda of policy leadership and entrepreneurship

title: Social Network Analysis for Public Policy
description: This course is designed to introduce students to the concepts and methods of social network analysis (SNA), including network types, levels of analysis, data collection, descriptive methods and inferential methods, and their applications in public policy, such as policy agenda setting, policy network, advocacy coalition, policy learning and diffusion, and policy implementation. It also familiarizes students with network analysis software (e.g., Python and/or R). This course is ideal for students with basic knowledge of data analytics who are interested in understanding and using SNA in public policy studies.

title: Natural Language Processing for Public Policy
description: This course is designed to introduce students to some common methods of Natural Language Processing (NLP), including text classification, topic modelling, text summarization, event extraction and text scaling, and their applications in public policy, such as data collection for evidence-based policymaking, interpretation of political decisions, policy communication, and investigation of policy effects. It also familiarizes students with some of the most useful Python libraries for NLP, for example, transformers, stanza and spaCy. Ethical issues are also discussed. This course is ideal for students with basic knowledge of machine learning who are interested in understanding and using NLP tools in data-driven policymaking.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Understand the principles behind the common NLP methods. Use the common Python libraries for NLP to solve problems. Describe the (mis-)uses of NLP in public policy.  Apply NLP tools to address actual policy issues and make better policy.

title: Internship
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with practical work experiences in the application of both data science and policy studies learned in DSPS programme. Students will be given opportunities to observe and experience the management operations and to have hands-on experience in public sector, non-government organizations (NGOs), private sector etc., and to experience the work life in the sector, as well as to nurture students’ practical skills. It is recommended that the internship to be conducted in summer holiday, i.e. June to August, after finishing year two studies in the block mode (i.e. 5 days x 8 hours). DSPS Programme will deploy work units, agencies, or organizations that provide internships relevant to the general course objectives. Meanwhile, students are encouraged to explore opportunities of internship to fit their own specific learning needs. However, all self-selected internship must comply with the course requirements, and subjected to the approval of DSPS Programme Director. Guidance and assistance will be provided whenever appropriate.During the internship, each student would be guided and assisted by an academic supervisor. The supervisor offers advice and help whenever necessary during the attachment period. At the same time, each student will be receiving guidance and assistance from his/her agency supervisor. Students will submit self-evaluation report to reflect on the experience in the internship. Academic advice will be provided to help students consolidate their learning in the internship.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Apply the learnt theories and knowledges into skills and practices in work experience Explore different career alternatives before they graduate Develop good work attitude which is essential to have job success Develop interpersonal skills, critical thinking skills and problem-solving skills which are applicable in both academic and working environment
syllabus: To be decided by the instructor and the internship organization

title: Advanced Data Visualization
description: This course is designed to equip students with the skills to convey data-driven insights clearly and effectively. The course begins with an introduction to data visualization and perception principles, followed by an overview of visualization design principles, data preparation and exploration, and advanced visualization techniques.Students will also learn about popular visualization tools (e.g., Tableau), virtual and augmented reality technologies, ethics and bias in data visualization, data storytelling, and data visualization for big data. The course concludes with a final project, where students apply the concepts learned throughout the course to create a high-impact data visualization using advanced technologies.This course is ideal for individuals with prior programming experience interested in exploring advanced data visualization techniques and technologies.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Create effective data visualizations that convey complex information in a clear and compelling way. Apply design principles and best practices to data visualization, including color theory, typography, and layout. Use advanced visualization techniques such as 3D visualizations, interactive dashboards, and emerging technologies such as virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR). Identify and avoid common pitfalls and biases in data visualization.

title: AI for Social Good
description: This course introduces students with basic coding skills to modern Artificial Intelligence (AI) and its societal impacts. It focuses on the techniques of deep learning and reinforcement learning, the workhorse of modern data-centric AI technologies and their applications. Ethical challenges and policy implications of these powerful AI technologies and applications are critically discussed and their positive and negative impacts on achieving the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) critically evaluated. The main concern of the course is how to ensure that these disruptive modern AI technologies are used to do good, rather than bad, to society. An emphasis is put on the need for dedicated regulatory AI policies, both at the national and international levels.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Discuss critically the (un)ethical use of AI technologies in society;  Understand the need for dedicated regulatory AI policies;  Appreciate the promising applications of AI technologies in achieving the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals;  Apply deep learning techniques to solve AI problems for social good.

title: Advanced Applications of Data Science in Public Policy
description: This is a special-topics course on advanced applications of data science in decision making, visualization, research, analytics and presentation techniques to inform policy decision-making. Topics covered would depend on knowledge and expertise of the instructor, and the latest development and innovations in the field. Students will be equipped with the most advanced capacities and methods to conduct data analytics related to policy decisions.

title: Data, Evidence and Public Policy
description: This course examines the fundamental principles and practices of evidence-based policymaking, emphasizing the role of data and empirical evidence in public policy design, implementation, and evaluation. Students will learn how to critically analyze policy issues through multiple lenses - empirical, normative, and practical - while developing skills in policy evaluation methodologies. The course covers the entire policy cycle, from problem identification to impact assessment, with particular attention to data collection, causal inference, and evaluation techniques. Through case studies across various policy domains, students will explore how evidence informs policy decisions and shapes public sector outcomes. The course combines theoretical frameworks with practical applications, preparing students to become sophisticated consumers and producers of policy evidence.

title: Graduation Capstone Project I
description: The graduation capstone project is about generating innovative ideas and implementing actionable knowledge to create impactful solutions. It offers students the opportunity to conduct a project on a selected topic under supervision related to data science and policy studies. While students are expected to integrate and apply what they have learned in the courses, internship, overseas exchanges and other learning opportunities, they are expected to address a real-world issue and to formulate feasible solutions and/or policy recommendations for the issue. Students are expected to meet their supervisor regularly, present their findings and exhibit their final product in any formats after developing a mutual consent between students and supervisor.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to: Identify a topic with a specific client in mind for generating innovative ideas and implementing actionable knowledge to create impactful solutions Identify previous academic works and innovative projects as references to their topic Consult client on the project topic, concerns and expectation Plan and organize the whole project design Collect and analyse data Present findings and policy recommendations
syllabus: 1. Identify the topic  2. Literature review 3. Client consultation and expectations assessment 4. Project design  5. Data collection and analysis  6. Presentation of findings and policy implementation
required_readings: To be decided by the course teacher concerned based on the topic selected
